§6. So strongly was it felt, Justlnian says, that a mandatum tua tantum gratia created no obligation, that people even extended the doubt to those which were for the benefit of a third person as well as of yourself: especially as it seems not improbable from Dig. 17. 1. 6. 4 (cited on 3 supr.) that a mandate aliena tanturn gratia was. also originally held to be void. Sometimes a person incurred a liability to compensate in caseos loss accruing to the other party even upon a mere consilium ; e. g. where by special contract he expressly undertook responsibility for his advice, and where the advice was given with evil intent, for the very purpose of damaging the other: ‘consilii non fraudulenti nulla obligatio est: ceterum si dolus et calliditas intercessit, de dolo actio competit’ Dig. 42. 1. 47. pr. : cf. the text, ‘nemo ex consilio mandati tenetur.³ .
